We operate sectors oil natural gas service industry: rental tools, international drilling, directional drilling services; casing tubing services; compressed air drilling services; production services. Our central operating strategy provide high-quality, technologically advanced services equipment. As result commitment customer service, developed strong relationships leading oil natural gas companies, including independents majors. </DIV> <DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV> <DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF"> Our growth strategy focused identifying pursuing opportunities markets growing faster oilfield services industry capitalize competitive strengths. Helmerich&#160;&#38; Payne, Inc. </DIV> <DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV> <DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF"> <I>Directional Drilling Services.</I>&#160;&#160;We utilize <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">state-of-the-art</FONT> equipment provide planning engineering services, directional drilling packages, downhole motor technology, site directional supervision, exploratory development re-entry drilling, downhole guidance services drilling services customers. We provide logging-while-drilling measurement-while-drilling services. We team approximately 85&#160;full-time directional drillers maintain selection approximately 160 drilling motors. According Baker Hughes, March&#160;2, 2007, 42% wells United States drilled directionally <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">and/or</FONT> horizontally. Risk Factors.&#148;</I> </DIV> <P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF"> <BR> 32 </DIV><!-- END LOGICAL --> <!-- PAGEBREAK --> <P><HR noshade><P> <H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table Contents</A></H5><P> <DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL --> <DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV> <DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF"> <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Overview Our Business</FONT></B> </DIV> <DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV> <DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF"> We multi-faceted oilfield services company services equipment oil natural gas exploration production companies, domestically Texas, Louisiana, New Mexico, Colorado, Oklahoma, Mississippi, Utah, Wyoming, Arkansas, Alabama, West Virginia, offshore Gulf Mexico, internationally, primarily Argentina Mexico. We operate sectors oil natural gas service industry: rental tools, international drilling, directional drilling services; casing tubing services; compressed air drilling services; production services. </DIV> <DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV> <DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF"> We derive operating revenues rates job charge labor equipment required provide service rates day equipment tools rent customers. The price charge services depends factors, including level oil natural gas drilling activity competitive environment geographic regions operate. Contracts awarded based price, quality service equipment, general reputation experience personnel. The demand drilling services historically volatile affected capital expenditures oil natural gas exploration development companies, fluctuate based prices oil natural gas expectation prices oil natural gas. </DIV> <DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV> <DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF"> The number working drilling rigs, typically referred &#147;rig count,&#148; important indicator activity levels oil natural gas industry. The rig count United States increased 862 December&#160;31, 2002 1,752 March&#160;2, 2007, Baker Hughes rig count. Furthermore, directional horizontal rig counts increased 283 December&#160;31, 2002 738 March&#160;2, 2007, accounted 33% 42% total U.S.&#160;rig count, respectively. </DIV> <DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV> <DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF"> Our cost revenues represents direct indirect costs operation maintenance equipment. The principal elements costs direct indirect labor benefits, repairs maintenance equipment, insurance, equipment rentals, fuel depreciation. Operating expenses fluctuate direct proportion revenues because, factors, fixed base inventory equipment facilities support operations, periods low drilling activity seek preserve labor continuity market services maintain equipment. </DIV> <DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV> <DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF"> <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Cyclical Nature Equipment Rental Services Industry</FONT></B> </DIV> <DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV> <DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF"> The oilfield services industry highly cyclical. The critical factor assessing outlook industry worldwide supply demand oil domestic supply demand natural gas. The peaks valleys demand cyclical industries. This primarily result industry driven commodity demand price increases. As demand increases, producers raise prices. The price escalation enables producers increase capital expenditures. The increased capital expenditures ultimately result greater revenues profits services equipment companies. The increased capital expenditures ultimately result greater production historically resulted increased supplies reduced prices. </DIV> <DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV> <DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF"> Demand services strong 2004, 2005 2006 due high oil natural gas prices increased demand declining production costs natural gas compared energy sources. Management believes current market fundamentals indicative favorable long-term trend activity markets. However, factors offset developments affecting worldwide supply demand oil natural gas products. </DIV> <DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV> <DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF"> <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Restatement</FONT></B> </DIV> <DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV> <DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF"> We understated diluted earnings share due incorrect calculation weighted shares outstanding quarters 2004, year ended December&#160;31, 2004 quarter ended March&#160;31, 2005. In addition, understated basic earnings share due incorrect calculation weighted average basic shares outstanding quarter ended September&#160;30, 2004. Consequently, restated financial statements periods. The incorrect calculation resulted mathematical error improper application Statement Financial Accounting Standards No.&#160;128<I>, &#147;Earnings Per Share&#148;, </I>or SFAS, No.&#160;128. The effect restatement reduce weighted average diluted shares outstanding relevant periods reduce weighted average basic shares </DIV> <P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF"> <BR> 33 </DIV><!-- END LOGICAL --> <!-- PAGEBREAK --> <P><HR noshade><P> <H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table Contents</A></H5><P> <DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN LOGICAL --> <DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF"> outstanding quarter ended September&#160;30, 2004. This statement requires share-based payments employees, including grants employee stock options, recognized financial statements based grant-date fair values. Compensation cost awards granted prior to, vested, January&#160;1, 2006 based grant date attributes originally awards pro forma purposes SFAS&#160;No.&#160;123, <I>Accounting Stock-Based Compensation</I> (&#147;SFAS&#160;No.&#160;123&#148;). We adopted SFAS&#160;No.&#160;123R modified prospective transition method, utilizing Black-Scholes option pricing model calculation fair employee stock options. We estimated forfeiture rates 2006 based historical experience. </DIV> <DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV> <DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF"> The Black-Scholes model incorporates assumptions stock-based awards. The risk-free rate interest related U.S.&#160;Treasury yield curve periods expected term option time grant. The dividend yield common stock assumed historically paid dividends current plans future. The expected volatility based historical volatility common stock. </DIV> <DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV> <DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF"> Prior January&#160;1, 2006, accounted stock-based compensation Accounting Principle Board Opinion No.&#160;25 (&#147;APB No.&#160;25&#148;). Under APB No.&#160;25, compensation expense recognized stock options exercise price market price grant date option. SFAS&#160;No.&#160;128 requires companies complex capital structures present basic diluted earnings share. Basic earnings share computed basis weighted average number shares common stock outstanding period. For periods April&#160;12, 2004, preferred dividends deducted net income considered calculation income common stockholders computing basic earnings share. Diluted earnings share similar basic earnings share, presents dilutive effect share basis potential common shares (e.g., convertible preferred stock, stock options, etc.) converted. We originally accounted formation AirComp joint venture. However February 2005, determined transaction accounted purchase accounting pursuant SFAS&#160;No.&#160;141, <I>Business Combinations </I>and recorded sale interest subsidiary, accordance SEC Staff Accounting Bulletin&#160;No.&#160;51, <I>Accounting Sales Stock Subsidiary.</I> Consequently, restated financial statements quarters ended September&#160;30, 2004, reflect adjustments: </DIV> <DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV> <DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF"> <I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Increase Book Value Fixed Assets.</FONT></I> </DIV> <DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV> <DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF"> Under joint venture accounting, originally recorded assets contributed M-I AirComp M-I&#146;s historical cost $6.9&#160;million. Under purchase accounting, increased recorded assets contributed M-I approximately $3.3&#160;million $10.3&#160;million reflect fair market determined party appraisal. In addition, joint venture accounting, established negative goodwill reduced fixed assets amount $1.6&#160;million. The negative goodwill amortized lives related fixed assets. Under purchase accounting, increased fixed assets $1.6&#160;million reverse negative goodwill previously recorded reversed amortization expenses recorded 2004. Therefore, cost fixed assets increased total $4.9&#160;million time acquisition. As result increase fixed assets reversal amortization negative goodwill, depreciation expense increased. </DIV> <DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV> <DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF"> The 2004 financial statements restated previously filed interim financial statements included <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">Form&#160;10-Q</FONT> first, quarters 2004.
